subject: In the Wind
event: The sharks are coming. Lots of them. Tonight on SyFy... and next month at the Jean Cocteau. Check it out. Next year's Hugo favorite, for sure.

comments.article: What is the airspeed velocity of an unladen swallow?

A one... a two... a three.......

**swallow**

comments.article:
I didn't even know there was a Sharknado 1 and Sharknado 2.

... Am I missing out?

Obviously the sharks are coming to kill anyone distracting you from writing your next book.

And possibly to make sure that you don't kill of Tyrion or Arya. ;-)
I saw that first line, "The sharks are coming," and then the picture popped up.  For some reason, that just started me laughing, and I couldn't stop.  I really needed that today.  Thanks George!!
comments.subject: Best laugh I've had all day!

comments.article: Speaking of sharks, have you read the JAWS novel by Peter Benchley. I haven't, since I've got other things on my reading list at the moment, but I've been meaning to for awhile.

Yes.

The movie was better.

(Not a phrase that you will often hear pass my lips).
I've been "Windrolled"!
comments.subject: Damn!

comments.article: I'll only watch it after Rifftrax has their way with it.
thanks for the heart attack george.
I for one welcome our new shark overlords. If god or buddha wanted me in the ocean, I would of been given gills. Now I have to worry about landsharks!

comments.article:
via RiffTrax in Cinemark on the Plaza. It was a hoot, though if I'd seen it on TV I'd want my hour and half of my life back...

Will be great fun though.

Hope you had fun filming it!
comments.subject: cameo

comments.article: So I just noticed that you had a cameo! That's too freaking cool! So how did that develop? (I liked the Red Wedding Reference)
comments.subject: Cameo

comments.article:
Somebody asked on my blog why you aren't wearing your iconic hat in Sharknado 3.

What is the inside story?
comments.subject: The kind of trivia fans pay attention to

comments.article: A sincere thank you, George R. R. Martin, for so much great entertainment over the decades.  It was an honor to have the pleasure of throwing sharks your way and hope you don't feel ill-used or sore from the results.  A peril of being in the grand theatre of life is that we sometimes get to experience the sharks that attack the stage. The North Remembers.  So does The Asylum.  The Sharks send their regards.  ;-)  Joseph J. Lawson, VFX Supervisor, The Global Asylum
comments.subject: Thank you!

comments.article: Thanks, Joseph.  It was a lot of fun.
comments.subject: Re: Thank you!

comments.article: What was watching your cameo like?
comments.subject: Cameo

comments.article: It's not every day you get your head bitten off by a shark.
comments.subject: Re: Cameo

comments.article:
Kind of off-topic but have you people heard of Fidel Castro's prophecy that has come true? "The US will come to talk to us when you have a black president and the world has a Latin American pope." Fidel, 1973

Reminded me of Mirri Maz Duur's Prophecy :-))
Call me skeptical, but somehow I doubt this.

I have an off-topic question, answer if it please you.

How do you feel about ASOIAF fan art?
I am a person who sews, and there seems to be a big debate going on in our community right now concerning copyright/licensing.
(I know, you're picturing little old ladies with canes arguing with each other)

I'm not speaking of any HBO stuff, what I mean is fan art created from an artist's vision of book related subject matter.
MY purpose for creating these are to make a quilt for my family. My sons and I love the books-they have given us much joy over the years since we discovered them-and the quilt will be our family heirloom, so to speak. I'm wondering if things like this are ok with you, or if you'd rather not have people sell craft charts that they create with your books in mind.

As for myself, I have never sold any of my works. I either give them away to people I deem worthy or keep them. I know some people most likely profit off such items, but I am not one of them.

Any thoughts from you on this matter would be most appreciated.
comments.subject: About Fan Art

comments.article:
I have no problem with fan art, so long as the artist is creating it only for his or her own personal use.

I don't mind the artists sharing it either -- at art shows at cons, on Deviant Art, wherever.

The only problem comes when and if the artist decides to commercialize their work and print it, sell it, whatever. That's where copyright problems come in.

Even there, though, there's no problem if my name and my titles and characters, etc. are not used. Anyone can paint a picture of a blond girl riding on a dragon and sell it. Just don't call it Daenerys on Drogon.
comments.subject: Re: About Fan Art
